data.text: Wahoo Elemnt Roam or Garmin 830 for Navigating on a Long Haul Bike Tour?

Wahoo Elemnt Roam or Garmin 830 for navigating on a long haul tour? We are not interested in tracking what we did or how fast. Just how to get from A to B safely along scenic routes. Insights and advice please. Some background We are currently in Europe for Northern Hemisphere summer. Thus far we have used our android phones with OSMAnd. I fried my phone on arrival in Madrid navigating from the airport in the hot sun. As a result my phone is pretty stuffed, in that it can't find gps or connect to wifi. OSMAnd still works for calculating routes etc. It has found some great routes but also some impassable ones . Our paper michelin maps are pretty useful for finding smaller roads but not any use for finding bike paths or navigating in cities. My questions are: what maps come with these devices? Are they free? how do others plan routes ? What apps do others use for planning routes Europe . How easy is it to transfer routes from a phone to the device? How obvious is it when you go off route? Thanks in advance.
Hammerhead Karoo 2
data.author: Will Taylor

data.text: Hi. I use Komoot for route planning and a wahoo bolt for the navigation. They sync very well and it means I can store the route on my phone as back up. The bolt doesn't automatically re-route you if you wander off coarse but the komoot app will. That said, the bolt definitely lets you know if you've gone wrong. Best bit about the bolt is the battery life.

data.text: I use Garmin 830 for navigating - however, I bought mine in North America, which means there are no maps on it for Europe. There are apparently hacks available to download European maps, but I was unsuccessful in my latest attempt. That was frustrating when I got to Crete and had no maps! Got by with maps.me on my phone, however. I used to have a Garmin 800 which had a port for replaceable map chips - I switched btwn Europe and North America all the time. SO - if you buy your 830 in Europe, you'll have good maps (but of course, not maps for North America).

data.text: Consider Hammerhead Karoo 2. I have the original Karoo. Both version (1 and 2) have beautiful screens easily readable even at high sun, an easy interconnection with Kamoot (if you pay the basic option in Kamoot), great rerouting options and a display with climb information. I use it for my tours, I plan 300-400km in advance, and just follow it on screen..
